  • Incorrect, because squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) presents with irregular ulceration, pain, and sometimes blood-stained otorrhea.

  • SCC is a malignant, destructive lesion, whereas osteomas are benign and slow-growing.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Osteomas of the external auditory canal are benign, pedunculated bony tumors arising from cancellous bone, typically presenting as single, smooth masses on the posterior wall of the osseous canal near its outer end. They are usually asymptomatic but may require surgical removal if they cause conductive hearing loss or canal obstruction.

 

Reference: P.L. Dhingra - Diseases of Ear, Nose, and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 107.

choices.text: Osteoma of the External Auditory Canal

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents to the ENT clinic with gradual hearing loss and occasional ear blockage. He has a history of frequent cold-water exposure due to surfing. Examination reveals multiple smooth, sessile bony swellings in the deeper part of the external auditory canal near the tympanic membrane. The tympanic membrane is normal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Exostoses ("Surfer’s Ear")

 

Exostoses are multiple, bilateral, sessile bony swellings arising from compact bone in the deep external auditory canal. They are strongly associated with repeated exposure to cold water, commonly seen in divers and surfers.

 

 

Key Features of Exostoses ("Surfer’s Ear"):

  • Multiple, smooth, sessile bony swellings in the deep external auditory canal (EAC).

  • Bilateral presentation is common.

  • Strong association with cold water exposure (e.g., swimmers, divers, surfers).

  • Gradual hearing loss and wax impaction due to narrowing of the EAC.

  • More common in males (3:1 ratio).

Management Approach:

  • Asymptomatic cases → No treatment required.

  • Symptomatic cases (hearing loss, recurrent wax impaction) → Surgical removal with a high-speed drill.

  • Avoid gouge and hammer due to proximity to the facial nerve.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Osteoma of the External Auditory Canal:

  • Incorrect, because osteomas are single, pedunculated, and unilateral, while exostoses are multiple, sessile, and bilateral.

  • Osteomas arise from cancellous bone, whereas exostoses arise from compact bone.

 

 

Option C. Cholesteatoma:

  • Incorrect, because cholesteatomas are keratinizing squamous lesions, not bony growths.

  • They typically present with chronic ear discharge, conductive hearing loss, and tympanic membrane perforation, none of which are seen in exostoses.

 

 

Option D. Malignant Otitis Externa:

  • Incorrect, because malignant otitis externa occurs in elderly diabetics or immunocompromised patients and is caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa.

  • It presents with severe pain, granulation tissue in the EAC, and possible facial nerve palsy, which are absent in this case.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Exostoses ("Surfer’s Ear") are multiple, bilateral, sessile bony growths in the deep external auditory canal, commonly seen in individuals with repeated cold-water exposure. Management is conservative if asymptomatic; surgical removal is indicated if they cause hearing loss or recurrent wax impaction.

 

Reference: P.L. Dhingra - Diseases of Ear, Nose, and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 107

choices.text: Squamous cell carcinoma of the external ear

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents with gradual hearing loss and a sensation of ear fullness in his right ear. He denies pain, discharge, or a history of infections. Otoscopic examination reveals a smooth, firm, skin-covered polypoid swelling in the outer part of the external auditory canal (EAC), attached to the posterior wall. The lesion is non-tender, and there is accumulation of cerumen and debris due to obstruction. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ceruminoma

 

A ceruminoma (ceruminous gland tumor) is a rare tumor arising from the modified sweat glands in the external auditory canal that secrete cerumen.

 

 

Key Features of Ceruminoma:

  • Smooth, firm, polypoid swelling covered with skin.

  • Arises in the outer part of the external auditory canal, often from the posterior or inferior wall.

  • Leads to retention of cerumen and debris due to meatal obstruction.

  • Malignant ceruminomas (adenocarcinomas) are more common than benign types (2:1 ratio).

Management Approach:

  1. Wide surgical excision (preferred due to a tendency to recur).

  2. Histological examination to rule out malignancy.

  3. Postoperative radiotherapy if malignancy is confirmed.

  4. Regular follow-up to monitor for recurrence.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Exostosis:

  • Incorrect, because exostoses are multiple, sessile, bony swellings found in the deep external auditory canal near the tympanic membrane.

  • Exostoses do not present as smooth, firm, polypoid masses like ceruminomas.

 

 

Option C. Cholesteatoma:

  • Incorrect, because cholesteatomas are keratinizing squamous lesions, not tumors of ceruminous glands.

  • They typically present with chronic ear discharge, granulation tissue, and bony erosion, which are absent in ceruminomas.

 

 

Option D. Squamous Cell Carcinoma of the External Ear:

  • Incorrect, because SCC usually presents with ulceration, pain, and possible bleeding, unlike the smooth, firm, polypoid appearance of a ceruminoma.

  • SCC is often associated with a history of chronic sun exposure or chronic otitis externa.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ceruminomas are tumors of ceruminous glands in the external auditory canal, presenting as smooth, firm, skin-covered polypoid swellings that can cause obstruction and cerumen retention. Management includes wide surgical excision, histological evaluation, and postoperative radiotherapy if malignancy is suspected.

 

Reference: P.L. Dhingra - Diseases of Ear, Nose, and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 107

choices.text: Squamous Cell Carcinoma of the External Ear

questions.text: A 60-year-old male presents with a painless, slow-growing mass in his right external auditory canal (EAC). He denies hearing loss, ear discharge, or recent infections. Otoscopic examination reveals a smooth, skin-covered swelling in the outer part of the meatus. The lesion is non-tender and does not involve the tympanic membrane. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sebaceous Adenoma

 

A sebaceous adenoma is a benign tumor arising from sebaceous glands in the external auditory canal. It presents as a smooth, skin-covered swelling in the outer part of the meatus.

 

 

Key Features of Sebaceous Adenoma:

  • Slow-growing, painless mass in the outer external auditory canal.

  • Smooth, skin-covered swelling (not ulcerated or friable).

  • Does not cause hearing loss unless large enough to obstruct the canal.

  • No associated otorrhea, pain, or bony involvement.

Management Approach:

  1. Surgical excision (definitive treatment).

  2. Histopathological examination to confirm diagnosis and rule out malignancy.

  3. Follow-up to monitor for recurrence.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Exostosis:

  • Incorrect, because exostoses are bony swellings, usually multiple, sessile, and found in the deep external auditory canal near the tympanic membrane.

  • Sebaceous adenomas are soft tissue tumors, not bony overgrowths.

 

 

Option C. Ceruminoma:

  • Incorrect, because ceruminomas arise from ceruminous glands, not sebaceous glands.

  • Ceruminomas tend to obstruct the meatus, leading to cerumen retention and debris accumulation, which is not seen in sebaceous adenomas.

 

 

Option D. Squamous Cell Carcinoma of the External Ear:

  • Incorrect, because SCC typically presents with ulceration, pain, bleeding, and progressive destruction, which are absent in this case.

  • SCC is often linked to chronic sun exposure, chronic otitis externa, or immunosuppression.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sebaceous adenomas are benign tumors of sebaceous glands in the external auditory canal, presenting as smooth, skin-covered swellings in the outer meatus. The treatment of choice is surgical excision, followed by histopathological evaluation to confirm diagnosis and rule out malignancy.

 

Reference: P.L. Dhingra - Diseases of Ear, Nose, and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 108

choices.text: Chronic suppurative otitis media with granulation tissue
Squamous cell carcinoma of the external auditory canal

questions.text: A 65-year-old male with a history of chronic ear discharge presents with blood-stained otorrhea and severe ear pain for the past few weeks. He has also noticed progressive facial weakness on the affected side. Otoscopic examination reveals an ulcerated lesion with granulation tissue and a friable, bleeding polypoid mass in the external auditory canal. Regional lymph nodes are enlarged. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Squamous Cell Carcinoma of the External Auditory Canal

 

Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) is the most common malignant tumor of the external auditory canal (EAC). It often arises in patients with a history of long-standing ear discharge (chronic otitis media) and presents with blood-stained discharge, severe ear pain, and facial nerve involvement due to tumor invasion.

 

 

Key Features of SCC of the External Ear:

  • History of chronic ear discharge (mucopurulent → becomes blood-stained).

  • Severe ear pain (otalgia), often disproportionate to the findings.

  • Ulcerated, friable, bleeding polypoid mass or granulations in the external auditory canal.

  • Facial nerve paralysis (CN VII involvement) → due to tumor extension through the posterior meatal wall.

  • Regional lymph node involvement (preauricular, postauricular, infraauricular, and upper deep cervical nodes).

Management Approach:

  1. Wide en bloc surgical excision (preferred treatment).

  2. Postoperative radiotherapy (to reduce recurrence).

  3. Lymph node evaluation and possible dissection if involved.

  4. Histopathological confirmation to differentiate from chronic inflammatory conditions (e.g., granulation tissue in chronic otitis media).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chronic Suppurative Otitis Media (CSOM) with Granulation Tissue:

  • Incorrect, because CSOM presents with painless chronic ear discharge, whereas SCC is associated with severe pain and blood-stained discharge.

  • Granulation tissue in CSOM does not ulcerate, bleed profusely, or cause facial nerve paralysis.

 

 

Option B. Malignant Otitis Externa:

  • Incorrect, because malignant otitis externa (MOE) is seen in diabetic or immunocompromised patients and is caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa.

  • MOE presents with granulation tissue at the floor of the EAC, cranial nerve involvement, and severe pain, but does not typically cause a friable mass or bleeding like SCC.

 

 

Option D. Ceruminoma:

  • Incorrect, because ceruminomas arise from ceruminous glands and present as smooth, skin-covered polypoid swellings without ulceration, bleeding, or nerve involvement.

  • Malignant ceruminous adenocarcinomas are rare and do not commonly present with facial paralysis or lymph node involvement.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) of the external auditory canal presents with chronic ear discharge that becomes blood-stained, severe otalgia, an ulcerated or polypoid bleeding mass, and possible facial nerve paralysis. Management involves en bloc surgical excision followed by postoperative radiotherapy.

 

Reference: P.L. Dhingra - Diseases of Ear, Nose, and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 108

choices.text: Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) of the external auditory canal
Basal cell carcinoma (BCC) of the external auditory canal

questions.text: A 70-year-old male presents with a painless ulcerated lesion on the posterior wall of his right external auditory canal. He has no history of chronic ear infections or discharge but has had progressive lesion growth over the past six months. On examination, the lesion appears slow-growing, pearly, and non-healing, with rolled edges and mild surface telangiectasia. There is no facial nerve involvement. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Basal Cell Carcinoma (BCC) of the External Auditory Canal

 

Basal cell carcinoma (BCC) is a rare malignant tumor of the external auditory canal (EAC). It is the most common skin cancer and occurs primarily in sun-exposed areas but can also arise in the external ear and meatus. Unlike squamous cell carcinoma (SCC), BCC does not typically metastasize but may cause local invasion.

 

 

Key Features of Basal Cell Carcinoma of the External Auditory Canal:

  • Painless, slow-growing ulcerated lesion.

  • Pearly appearance with rolled edges and surface telangiectasia.

  • No history of chronic ear infections or discharge (unlike SCC).

  • Facial nerve involvement is rare unless locally invasive.

Diagnosis:

  • Biopsy is necessary to differentiate BCC from SCC.

Management:

  1. Wide surgical excision (preferred treatment).

  2. Postoperative radiotherapy (for locally advanced cases).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Squamous Cell Carcinoma (SCC) of the External Auditory Canal:

  • Incorrect, because SCC typically presents with blood-stained discharge, severe otalgia, and rapid progression.

  • SCC lesions are friable, ulcerated, and may cause facial nerve involvement, unlike the slow-growing, pearly appearance of BCC.

 

Option C. Malignant Otitis Externa:

  • Incorrect, because MOE occurs in elderly diabetics or immunocompromised patients due to Pseudomonas aeruginosa.

  • Presents with severe ear pain, granulation tissue at the floor of the external auditory canal, and cranial nerve involvement.

 

Option D. Exostosis:

  • Incorrect, because exostoses are multiple, sessile, bony swellings that arise due to cold water exposure (e.g., in surfers and divers).

  • Exostoses do not ulcerate, bleed, or cause rolled edges, as seen in BCC.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Basal cell carcinoma (BCC) of the external auditory canal presents as a slow-growing, ulcerated lesion with rolled edges and surface telangiectasia. Diagnosis is confirmed by biopsy, and management involves wide surgical excision with postoperative radiotherapy if necessary.

 

Reference: P.L. Dhingra - Diseases of Ear, Nose, and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, 6th Edition, Page 108
